channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for FL

item.title: Report E-2024070189
item.description:
Report E-2024070189

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-12T15:12:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-01
  • City: OCALA
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 1, 2024, two (2) 5-gallon pails of paint were punctured by a forklift and released approximately one half (0.5) of a gallon of paint to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Alpha-Omega Training and Compliance (AOTC) to remediate the impacted site. AOTC overpacked the damaged pails in two (2) 55-gallon drums. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to collect and containerize all impacted material in one (1) additional 55-gallon drum.

item.title: Report E-2024070097
item.description:
Report E-2024070097

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-08T18:15:44+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-28
  • City: LAKELAND
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LANDSTAR INWAY, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On June 28, 2024, at 1248 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Lakeland, Florida regarding the release of Injection Sour. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of 10 gallons of Injection Sour (UN3412, 8, II) from (1) 55-gallon plastic drum. The release was caused by the drum being crushed from a load shift and contained to the trailer floor. Contractors transferred the remaining product in the damaged drum to a new 55-gallon plastic drum without complication. Contractors then neutralized and cleaned the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. All waste was containerized in (1) 55-gallon DF and staged onsite by contractors for proper disposal.
